Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Marketing, Advertising and PR

abstract.p: aQuantive chief executive Brian P McAndrews is expected to make $134 million from Microsoft's $6 billion acquisition of company; chief strategy officer Michael Galgon is set to make $44.6 million; unlike executives in many recent mergers, where reimbursements of tax bill--called tax gross-ups--on all stock are often part of deal, aQuantive's executives will not get gross-ups (S)

block.p: As with most mergers, top executives at aQuantive stand to make a lot of money by cashing in stock and exercising options now that Microsoft has agreed to acquire the company for $6 billion.

Brian P. McAndrews, the chief executive of aQuantive, an online advertising firm, is expected to make $134 million from the deal. Michael Galgon, the chief strategy officer, is set to make $44.6 million, according to the preliminary merger proxy filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission last week.
As with most mergers, top executives at aQuantive stand to make a lot of money by cashing in stock and exercising options now that Microsoft has agreed to acquire the company for $6 billion.

Brian P. McAndrews, the chief executive of aQuantive, an online advertising firm, is expected to make $134 million from the deal. Michael Galgon, the chief strategy officer, is set to make $44.6 million, according to the preliminary merger proxy filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission last week.

But unlike executives in many recent mergers, where reimbursements of the tax bill -- called tax gross-ups -- on all the stock are often part of the deal, aQuantive's executives will not get gross-ups.
Jamie Leady, a spokeswoman for aQuantive, which is based in Seattle, declined to comment.
